bibl.title: Letter from Pedro Nogueira to Albert E. Truby, November 15, 1941

div1.p: Nogueira informs Truby that he will contribute to a local history of Marianao, which is currently being written. He inquires about the locations of the mosquito experiments, where Lazear died, where Edmunds was confined, and the role of Cuban doctors in the Yellow Fever Commission's work.

div1.head: Letter from Pedro Nogueira to Albert E. Truby, November 15, 1941
div1.opener:

DR. PEDRO NOGUEIRA
UNIDAD SANITARIA DE MARIANAO
SAMA No. 21 - MARIANAO
Marianao Novembre 15 of 1941.
Albert. E. Truby
Brigadier General, U.S.A.- Medical Corps.- Retired.
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco.- California.
U.S.A.
Dear Brigadier:
div1.p:
I hope you will excuse me for adressing you these lines, but it is
due to your direct contact with research work done on Yellow Fever, carried out
in Cuba during the years of the American Intervention in our Country. As in my
recors it seems that you were assigned to the Hospital at the Barracks in Camp
Columbia during the last months of 1899, as well as 1900, I am hoping you can
furnish me with some data in regard to some points which I want to check up on;
said points are de followings:

FIRST.- Can you inform me in which place at Camp Columbia Dr Lazear practiced
innoculations with mosquitoes (which I believe were eight cases) on American
volunteer soldiers during the month of August, 1900?.- I presume thet the ino-
culation practiced on Dr Carroll and on Private Dean were performed at the same
place by Dr Lazear. Is this correct?.- Would you please state whether this was
the place where Dr Ames had his so called “Yellow Fever Wards”, to attend yellow
fever cases, or if on the contrary, the place I am investigating was one separa-
te from the Camp (which I name “Truby and Ames Camp for Yellow Fever Cases”.-
I think the place I refer to problably was a locality with a Laboratory, for I
believe it was here where the members of the American Commision began their re-
search work in the month of June 1900, to determine whether the Sanarelli Baci-
llus were the cause of Yellow Fever.

SECOND.- Can you inform me the exact place where Dr Lazear died?.- I was told
that he died at the “Truby and Ames Camp for Yellow Fever Cases” that I mencio-

ned before. Is this correct?-

THIRD:- Do you remember Major Edmunds ever being confined to the “Truby and Ames
Camp for Yellow Fever Cases”, during his yellow fever attack, which caused his death?
I am quite sure he died on June 16, 1900,18 at No 17 Gen Lee St AET
but I am uncertain where.

FOURTH:- What sort of work were doctors Angles, Herrera and Silverio in charge of in
regard to the work of the American Commision.

On account of needing this data to be accurate for the local history of Maria-
nao, where I have assigned to write about the part referring to Yellow Fever, and
the research carried out during the different periods of time in this town, I am
taking the liberty of your kindness requesting this information. I hope you reply
will be of great value for my records and work.

Furthemore, if it be possible, I would like to have one of your photographs.
One of that epoc or as nearedt as possible, for it is my desire to illustrate my
report with photographs of everyone in regard to this subject.
div1.closer:
Respectfully yours: Dr Pedro Nogueira
Marianao Health Unit.
